text.*:
This is a timeline of Capital Radio, from the very first days as a single station in London to the current day semi-national Capital network.

Contents

  • 1 1970s
  • 2 1980s
  • 3 1990s
  • 4 2000s
  • 5 2010s
  • 6 References

1970s[edit]

  • 1970
    • Radio Capital, later to become Capital Radio, is formed in early 1970 by David Maule-ffinch with the intent to apply for London’s Independent Local Radio general entertainment licence. In late 1970, Maule-ffinch's future father-in-law, Barclay Barclay-White became involved. The Radio Capital team that was finally in place at the time of application to the IBA included Sir Richard Attenborough, Sir George Martin, Bryan Forbes, Sir Peter Saunders, David Maule-Ffinch and Barclay Barclay-White.[1]
  • 1973
    • February – Capital Radio is awarded the licence to provide London’s general entertainment service.
    • 16 October – Capital London begins broadcasting a music-based general entertainment service to the London area.[2]. Launching eight days after LBC, Capital becomes the UK’s second Independent Local Radio. The station broadcasts on 95.8 MHz FM from the Croydon transmitter and 557 kHz (539 m) MW from London Transport's Lots Road Power Station, Chelsea. The medium-wave frequency and location were temporary sites as the then new high-powered medium-wave station at Saffron Green, Barnet, was incomplete. "Bridge over Troubled Water" by Simon & Garfunkel is the first record.
  • 1974
    • January –
      • The station changes its music policy following a slow start, moving away from light music to a more pop-based format.
      • Kenny Everett joins to present the breakfast show.
    • 2 September – Michael Aspel joins to host the weekday mid-morning programme.
  • 1975
    • The IBA finally opens the station’s permanent transmission facilities at Saffron Green which allows both LBC and Capital Radio to move up the dial. Capital moved to 1548 kHz mediumwave (194 m).
  • 1976
    • December – Capital London launches the Capital Radio Helpline.
    • Capital London launches the Flying Eye, a traffic spotting light aircraft, which reports on traffic congestion on the streets of Central London.
  • 1977
    • No events.
  • 1978
    • June – Mike Smith joins.
    • November – Original presenter Tommy Vance leaves for BBC Radio 1.
  • 1979
    • 31 December – Alan Freeman joins and hosts The Top 40 of the 70s.

1980s[edit]

  • 1980
    • 7 January – Alan Freeman revives The Rock Show.
    • July – Mike Smith takes over as presenter of the breakfast show.
    • August – Richard Allinson joins to present Capital’s weekly chart show. He also presents various other shows on the station during his time at Capital, including the late show from 1984 until 1987, the afternoon show (1987-1990) and lastly the early morning show.
  • 1981
    • No events.
  • 1982
    • 13 March – Pick of the Pops returns when Alan Freeman revives the name on Capital Radio. The programme is called Pick of the Pops Take Two.
    • Mike Smith leaves to rejoin BBC Radio 1.
  • 1983
    • No events.
  • 1984
    • June – Kenny Everett rejoins Capital, reviving his Saturday lunchtime show.
    • 30 September – The first edition of The Network Chart Show is broadcast. Aired on almost all of the UK's Independent Local Radio network, the programme is presented from the studios of Capital Radio by David Jensen. David, who joined from BBC Radio 1, also presents the station’s mid-morning programme.
    • 30 December – Michael Aspel leaves. Latterly he had been presenting a Sunday show having left the weekday mid-morning show five months earlier.
  • 1985
    • No events.
  • 1986
    • 4 May – As part of an experiment in split broadcasting, Capital runs a Sunday service called CFM, broadcasting a more contemporary mix of music than normally broadcast by the station.
  • 1987
    • March – Chris Tarrant takes over as host of the breakfast show.
    • October – Neil Fox joins.
  • 1988
    • After a year at the station, Jackie Brambles leaves for BBC Radio 1.
    • June – Roger Scott leaves for BBC Radio 1. He had been at the station since its launch 15 years earlier.
    • 2 July – At 7am, Tony Blackburn launches Capital Gold. The station initially broadcasts only at the weekend. Other launch include David Hamilton, Paul Burnett, Paul Gambaccini and Kenny Everett. [3]
    • 1 November – 1548 AM Capital Gold begins full-time broadcasting. The FM service is renamed as 95.8 Capital FM.
    • At the end of 1988, Alan Freeman leaves to rejoin BBC Radio 1. This signals the end of ‘’Pick of the Pops Take Two’’.
  • 1989
    • No events.

1990s[edit]

  • 1990
    • No events.
  • 1991
    • No events.
  • 1992
    • No events.
  • 1993
    • Capital Radio Group buys BRMB.
  • 1994
    • Capital Radio Group buys Southern Radio Group.[4]
    • April – Alan Freeman joins Capital Gold and revives Pick of the Pops. The programme is called Pick Of The Pops – Take Three.
    • Original presenter Dave Cash leaves after 21 years at the station.
  • 1995
    • No events.
  • 1996
    • September – Capital launches its website.
    • October – News programme The Way It Is ends.
  • 1997
    • Steve Penk joins to host the mid-morning show.
    • Richard Allinson leaves.
  • 1998
    • Capital Gold Birmingham replaces Xtra AM.
    • 1 June Capital Gold launches in the south, replacing South Coast Radio.[5][6]
  • 1999
    • Following the company’s purchase of Red Dragon FM and its medium wave service Touch Radio in South Wales, Capital Gold replaces Touch Radio.
    • 15 November – Life launches on the new Digital One national multiplex.

2000s[edit]

  • 2000
    • May – Capital Radio buys Border Radio Holdings, thereby acquiring the three Century radio stations.[7]
  • 2001
    • No events.
  • 2002
    • The Capital Gold network relaunches with the new slogan of ‘’The Greatest Hits of the 60s, 70s and 80s.’’
    • After two years at Virgin Radio, Steve Penk rejoins to present a networked late evening show. However, he only stays for a short period returning to Key 103 in the new year.
  • 2003
    • December – Martin Collins leaves after almost 20 years at the station.
  • 2004
    • 2 April – After hosting 4,425 breakfast shows over 17 years, Chris Tarrant leaves. [8] He is succeeded by Johnny Vaughan.
  • 2005
    • Spring – Neil Fox leaves.
    • May – Capital Radio Group and GWR Group merge to form GCap Media.
    • DAB station Life is relaunched as Capital Life with a full presenter line-up. This didn’t last long as in the new year the presenters, apart from breakfast, were dropped.
    • December – A new policy started of two advertisements in each break to win favour with listeners, though there were more frequent breaks as a result. This policy was changed within a few months.
  • 2006
    • 9 January – Capital is relaunched under its original name Capital Radio, with a modified line-up of presenters and a slightly tweaked music format.
    • September – The January tweaks are not judged to be a success. A new programme controller, Scott Muller came from the Nova group in Australia, and the station sees another tweak in style and brands itself as "London's Hit Music Station”.
  • 2007
    • March – The station is rebranded once again. It is renamed Capital 95.8 and its slogan becomes "The Sound of London”.
    • 3 August – All stations in the Classic Gold and Capital Gold networks are replaced by a new network called simply Gold, the result of the merger of the Classic Gold and Capital Gold networks under one owner, GCap Media.
    • 10 December – Following further slips down the listening charts which sees it now down to fourth place in London, the tagline of ‘’London’s Hit Music Network’’ returns, Greg Burns replaces Lucio on drivetime with Lucio moving to the evening show, replacing Bam Bam who leaves the station.
  • 2008
    • 4 February – Denise Van Outen joins to co-host the breakfast show with Johnny Vaughan. [9] Ashe leaves after just six months, on 29 July.[10]
    • 31 March –
      • DAB station Capital Life closes.
      • Global Radio agrees to purchase Capital’s owners GCap Media for £375million.[11]
    • August – Lisa Snowdon replaces Denise Van Often as breakfast co-presenter.[12][13]
    • 31 October – Global Radio officially takes control of all GCap Media and its brands, giving it ownership of The One Network. The GCap Media name is dropped at this time.
  • 2009
    • No events.

2010s[edit]

  • 2010
    • 13 September – Global announces plans to scrap the Galaxy Network in order to create a nationwide Capital FM. The plans will also include the closure of four further stations, with the new network going live in early 2011.[14]
  • 2011
    • 3 January – 95.8 Capital FM London launches nationally and becomes a part of The Capital FM Network as part of a merger of Global Radio's Hit Music and Galaxy networks to form the nine-station 'Capital Network'.[15] Other than daily breakfast and weekday drivetime shows, the majority of Capital's London-based output is now networked.[16]
    • 1 July – Global Radio requests changes to the formats of Capital Birmingham and Capital Scotland, which had inherited obligations from previous owners. This was to enable format consistency within all nine Capital stations.[17] On 17 November 2011, Ofcom approved both format change requests.[18]
    • November After more than seven years, Johnny Vaughan presents Capital Breakfast for the final time. He is replaced by Dave Berry[19] who hosts the show until April 2017.
  • 2012
    • 12 October – Global launches Capital TV on Freesat and Sky.[20]
  • 2013
    • 8 March – 95.8 Capital FM hires former BBC Radio 1 journalist Dominic Byrne to work on its breakfast show with presenters Dave Berry and Lisa Snowdon.[21]
    • 7 October – Urban music station Choice FM is rebranded as Capital XTRA, broadcasting on FM in London on 96.9 and 107.1 MHz and nationally on the Digital One DAB multiplex.[22]
  • 2014
    • 6 February – Global Radio announces that is will be selling two of its Capital stations – in Scotland and South Wales – to Communicorp. Capital's network programming and brand name is still used by both stations under contract.[23]
    • 6 May – Capital North West and Wales launches, following the launch of Heart North Wales. It replaces Heart North Wales & West which had broadcast to Cheshire, the Wirral Peninsula and North Wales. [24]
  • 2015
    • 13 November – Lisa Snowdon announces that she will leave Capital Breakfast at the end of the year.[25]
  • 2016
    • 18 January – Following Global Radio's purchase of Liverpool station Juice 107.6, the station is relaunched as Capital Liverpool.[26]
  • 2017
    • No events.
  • 2018
    • 2 August – Having purchased Brighton and Hove station Juice 107.2 earlier in the year, Global announces the service will be relaunched as Capital Brighton from Monday 3 September.[27]
